title-group.article-title: The Interaction of Capital Structure and Ownership Structure*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2005 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: We develop a model of the interaction of firms' capital and ownership structures. The structures are designed to trade off managerial discipline versus managerial initiative. Debt features constrain managerial choice following poor firm performance. Equity ownership dispersion increases managerial initiative, by granting some managerial freedom following high firm performance. The empirical predictions are: equity ownership should be concentrated when debt is closely held, effective debt covenants are present, bankruptcy procedures and the institutional environment are creditor friendly, and board representation of lenders is commonplace. By contrast, equity should be dispersed if long‐term investments are more important than short‐term project selection.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There is a growing consensus among academics and practitioners that both the design and the ownership patterns of financial securities have a significant impact on the creation of value in large corporations. Economists1and legal scholars2have examined the effect that large shareholders have on firm behavior. Others have analyzed the role of large lenders as well as small, dispersed owners of debt securities.3Among practitioners, theWall Street Journal(1995) has examined the role played by significant individual shareholders, while theInstitutional Investor(1985) is one example of a discussion on the role of financial institutions as shareholders. Separately, there exists a long literature and debate on the optimal capital structure and its effects on corporate performance.4

This paper models the ownership structure and capital structure jointly, generating a vehicle with which we can examine interaction effects and make predictions for use in empirical studies. Many aspects of the financial structure interact: the ownership dispersion of a particular class of claims among investors, the shape of their return rights, the presence of covenants and other restrictions, the representation of particular classes of securities on the corporate board, as well as features of the institutional environment, such as the bankruptcy law. Understanding these interactions and developing a comprehensive guide for the empirical investigation of both ownership and capital structure are the main contributions of this paper. Furthermore, in developing a model with multiple securities owned by different classes of investors, the paper begins to answer a fundamental question posed in the recent literature (Tirole2001, p. 19): “Explaining the coexistence of multiple securities with differentiated control rights is one of the main challenges currently facing corporate finance theory.”

The empirical predictions arising from the model are equity ownership should be concentrated whenever debt is also closely held and equity should be dispersed whenever dispersed debt is used to finance the firm. This is consistent with the stylized differences between German/Japanese structures and U.S./U.K. financial structures. Furthermore, equity ownership should be concentrated whenever bankruptcy procedures and other features of the institutional environment are creditor friendly, when effective debt covenants can be imposed, and when board representation of bankers is commonplace.5On the other hand, equity should be dispersed if long‐term investments are more important for firm value than short‐term project selection. More generally, the model implies that any empirical analysis should include both the ownership structure and the capital structure features of firms, because omitting one or the other could lead to loss of explanatory power or even biased results.

The implications of the model derive from the following intuition: a firm's manager prefers some types of owners to others, because different types have differential abilities to constrain her choices. As a consequence, the manager acts to maximize firm value if such “favorite” owners remain in charge only following high firm performance. The optimal financial structure thus employs tough debt, which takes over following poor firm performance, and relatively weaker equity, which is attractive to the manager but retains control only if firm performance is high. The degree of dispersion of ownership of both debt and equity, as well as other features like debt covenants, bankruptcy rights, and board representation of different types of investors, all affect the powers of the various investor groups vis‐à‐vis the manager. Balancing the various features results in an optimal financial structure, which can then be analyzed to examine interaction effects among the features.

Ownership plays a vital role. The model shows that an individual owner is strong vis‐à‐vis management, because such an owner gathers information to protect her large investment. This information allows the owner to implement alternatives to management proposals. Dispersed owners, by contrast, are weak because it is not worth their while to gather information due to their small stake in the firm. While the strength of concentrated ownership is useful in constraining and disciplining management, this tight control also reduces the incentives of the manager to create profits. This is because a strong, individual owner cannot commit not to take advantage of management in the future (say, by agreeing to a takeover that replaces management). Only when equity ownership is dispersed can management expect to always remain in power following high firm performance, because dispersed owners find it difficult to overrule management decisions. The optimal ownership structure trades off the ability of strong owners to discipline management versus the stimulating effect dispersed equity owners have for managerial initiative.

Other capital structure features interact with the ownership structure. Debt covenants make debt holders stronger and more able to overrule management. Hence, management is even more motivated to avoid debt control. This additional motivation allows the firm to have less‐dispersed (stronger) equity, without destroying managerial incentives to keep equity in power with high firm performance. Hence, strong debt makes strong equity feasible. Similarly, a creditor‐friendly bankruptcy law makes debt holders stronger, allowing again for stronger (more‐concentrated) equity ownership. Board representation for large lenders acts in the same way. Overall, the ownership structure interacts with the features of both debt contracts and the firm's institutional environment, generating testable implications.

One specific application of the model is the analysis of the initial public offering (IPO) process. As pointed out by several authors, various mechanisms affect the allocation of ownership shares during the IPO process.6These authors have found that there are benefits to large owners emerging, as well as benefits to having dispersed ownership. This paper shows how to strengthen these studies by controlling for capital structure differences across firms as well as differences in the institutional environment. These controls might shed light on the unresolved issues in the literature.

Another example of an application of the model is the comparison of firms under different bankruptcy laws. Franks, Nyborg, and Torous (1996), as well as others, have pointed out significant differences in bankruptcy law across both time (changes are introduced periodically) and countries (the law in the United Kingdom is much more creditor friendly than in the United States). This paper allows for an examination of the ownership structure in light of these institutional differences. As pointed out above, equity ownership should be more concentrated in environments with creditor‐friendly bankruptcy laws. Furthermore, the model allows for empirical tests of the consequences of bankruptcy law changes that control for other features of the capital and ownership structure, such as the presence of lenders on the corporate board, which also differs across countries.7

Finally, the optimal capital structure and ownership structure developed in the model are stable. We show that debt and equity holders have no incentive to renegotiate their securities outside financial distress, and equity holders have no incentive to trade away from their optimal ownership allocation. Even with unmodeled, real‐world effects like taxes or regulation that cause investors to hold securities in certain quantities, the direction of the interaction effects will remain as determined in this paper. For example, even if the tax law leads firms to issue more debt relative to equity, it still is true that changes in the bankruptcy laws have the predicted effect on equity ownership. To complete the analysis, the model shows that introducing optimally designed monetary incentive schemes for managers (salary, bonus, stock options, etc.) does not undermine the results. This is because the allocation of power to owners and management via the ownership and capital structure provides an additional, and often relatively inexpensive, mechanism to affect managerial behavior.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows: after a brief literature review, Section III presents a short numerical example to examine the basic intuition. Next, section IV introduces the formal model. Section V discusses the implications of the model and examines extensions and robustness. Section VI concludes.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Related Literature
sec.p: Early models, which focus exclusively on the capital structure of firms, include Modigliani and Miller (1958), Jensen and Meckling(1976), Myers(1977), Ross(1977), and Myers and Majluf(1984). Some of the more‐recent contributions that explicitly incorporated an active role for outside investors are Diamond (1984,1991,1993), Aghion and Bolton(1992), Berglöf and von Thadden (1994), Rajan and Winton(1995), Bolton and Scharfstein(1996), and Acemoglu(1998)on the debt side; Shleifer and Vishny(1986), Burkart et al. (1997), and Myers(2000)on the equity side; and Boot and Thakor (1993), Dewatripont and Tirole(1994), Berkovitch and Israel(1996), and Habib and Johnsen(2000)on debt and equity together.

The papers closest in spirit to the present discussion are Aghion and Bolton(1992), Dewatripont and Tirole(1994), and Burkart et al. (1997). Aghion and Bolton show that a contingent allocation of control rights to debt holders can lead to improved decisions by managers. However, no ownership structure considerations or institutional effects appear in their model. Dewatripont and Tirole discuss the effect of assigning control rights to multiple, different outside investors. Their focus is on the interaction of cash flow rights and control rights, but they do not address ownership implications, institutional predictions, or implications for monitoring. Burkart et al. examine the consequences of equity dispersion, but they do not model the firm's capital structure.

Some papers that provide the technical foundation for the model in the paper are Aghion and Tirole(1997), Grossman and Hart(1986), and Hart and Moore(1990). Aghion and Tirole propose a difference between real and formal authority in organizations.8This is akin to the fact that equity holders in this paper have legal rights to make decisions, but their dispersed nature reduces their real authority when it comes to controlling management. However, Aghion and Tirole do not analyze the financial structures of firms.9Grossman and Hart, as well as Hart and Moore, provide the foundation for the incomplete contracting environment used in this paper, where the allocation of control rights assures that parties make relationship specific investments.
The relationship of the current paper to the existing empirical literature is discussed in Section V, after the empirical predictions of the model have been developed.

fn.p: Early work in this area was done by Berle and Means (1932), who examine the limits to the real powers of equity holders who hold all legal rights to make decisions.

Crémer (1995) independently discusses the relationship between effective control and information. See also Stein(2002)on hierarchies and Liberti(2003)for an interesting empirical examination of the issue.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: A Numerical Example
sec.p: Before developing the formal model, we examine a short numerical example that illustrates the main ideas.

Imagine a firm that must make two sequential decisions: how to downsize to cut costs (a long‐term strategic decision) and later whether to move to a new office building, either downtown or in the suburbs (a short‐term project choice). The top manager of the firm is needed to implement the downsizing, because she has the necessary information and expertise. In general, however, management also has preferences that differ from simple firm value maximization. In fact, the manager might resist the optimal amount of downsizing, because she views that option as an admission of past failures or it might impede her career progress or entail breaking implicit promises to workers and middle managers. Similarly, she might derive private benefits from moving into nice new headquarters downtown, even if this is not firm value maximizing.

The numerical consequences of these actions are as follows: downsizing leads to an increase in firm value of $30 million, but a loss of the top manager's utility of 2. Not downsizing leaves firm value and managerial utility unchanged. Moving to a new office downtown leads to a loss in firm value of $10 million, but a gain in managerial utility of 6. Moving into a new office in suburbia leads to a loss in firm value of $5 million and a gain in managerial utility of 3. Not moving leads to no change in firm value or managerial utility.Figure 1summarizes the numerical example. Fig. 1.—
Numerical Example

The locus of control in the firm affects which decisions get implemented. If given full legal control rights, the manager would not downsize and would move to the new office downtown for an overall loss in firm value of $10 million. If investors retain the full control rights, they could block the office move, but this would provide no incentive for the manager to implement the downsizing, leading to an overall gain/loss of $0. If the manager is given full control only following high firm performance (which depends on the downsizing), she would indeed downsize and lose utility of 2, because she could then use her control to move the office downtown and gain utility of 6. The overall gain in firm value would be $20 million. The most efficient solution would be for the manager to get some limited control only following high firm performance, which would get her to downsize for a utility loss of 2, then move the office to suburbia for a utility gain of 3. This would lead to a gain in firm value of $25 million. Note that there is no way to provide incentives to the manager to downsize and at the same time block all office moves.10

This paper points out how the firm's capital structure and the allocation of ownership rights can achieve the optimum outcome. The firm should have dispersed equity owners and closely held debt. The debt is designed so that a single debt holder obtains control when firm performance is poor (i.e., he takes over following bankruptcy, which is triggered when the firm does not downsize). The concentrated debt ensures that the debt holder finds it worthwhile to monitor the firm, and the information so gathered allows him to block any inefficient office move. But if the manager implements the downsizing, equity owners remain in control. Because they are small and dispersed, they face a cost of overruling the manager when it comes to the office move. This cost comes from an information disadvantage (the model shows that these small owners do not find it worthwhile to monitor). The optimal equity ownership dispersion induces a cost of action between $5 million and $10 million. This cost makes a move of the firm to suburbia for $5 million not costly enough for equity investors to act, but they would intervene if management suggests moving to a glitzy new office downtown for $10 million.

Intuitively, the dispersed equity acts as a commitment device. It allows management some limited freedom following good performance; and this freedom, together with the threat of debt control, motivates management to maximize overall firm value.

fn.p: As is shown later in the paper, getting managers to act in the investors' interests with purely monetary incentive schemes (stocks, options, salaries, and bonuses) can be rather expensive and inefficient. Hence, for simplicity, we assume here that these schemes areunavailable.

sec.title: The Model
sec.p: This section develops the basic model under some simplifying assumptions. Section V analyzes the results in the context of real‐world institutions and relaxes the simplifying assumptions.

Contractibility and Control Rights.All cash flows in the model are contractible, while effort choices, monitoring, and project choices are not.Contractiblemeans that courts can observe financial outcomes and payments and enforce contracts and securities that include them. Noncontractible choices may still be observable to managers and investors, but contracts cannot be written on them. This is because, att=0, it is impossible to specify exactly what course of action to choose, in a manner that can be enforced by a court of law. Hart(1995)and others discuss this specification at length. Of course, the inability to lay out all future courses of action in a contract is the very reason that firms are run by managers and not automatons.18

As the project decision γ cannot be contractually specified ex ante, the control rights of the firm matter. They are assigned via the firm's securities to any class of the investors or to management. The assignment of control rights can depend on all contractible variables in the model; in particular, it can depend on the realization of the first‐period cash flow. This means, for example, that securities can specify a reallocation of control rights from equity holders to debt holders following missed payments.

fn.p: Assuming initial ownership by a financially constrained manager would lead to qualitatively similar optimal contracts, because the contracts derived here maximize the firm's ability to raise funds.

This allocation can be achieved in an IPO or other initial firm “birth,” like an equity carve-out, a spin‐off, etc. Alternatively, the optimal allocation can be thought of as the equilibrium of an (unmodeled) market mechanism that maximizes firm value.

The fact that monitoring takes place after the project proposal simplifies the model considerably. Other timing options lead to similar results, but the issues of stochastic monitoring and the observability of monitoring itself would surface without adding new insights.

For simplicity, we assume that second‐period cash flows depend only on project choice and not first‐period effort. This assumption is relaxed in section V.F and does not affect the main results of the paper (relaxing it offers some additional insights about short‐term versus long‐term effects).
This is also the specification used in the previous literature (e.g., in Burkart et al.1997).

This assumption could be endogenized without generating further insights. If all investors' signals were identical, then a small fixed‐cost component in the monitoring cost would make free riding the equilibrium outcome. If signals for investors were not identical and/or otherwise identical investors played mixed strategies, then multiple parties would monitor, but the largest investor in a given class would still monitor with the greatest intensity and have, on average, the best information.

Following low cash flows, on the other hand, the required debt payments are high enough to cause the firm to default, shifting the control rights to the single, concentrated debt holder (dispersed debt is addressed in Sec. V.B). Furthermore, the face value of the debt is high enough that management cannot raise new funds to avoid debt control. The concentrated debt investor has enough capital at stake to choose to monitor very closely and allow no freedom to management. As a result, management has incentives to work hard to ensure that firm performance is high and equity remains in power.

As an important next step, we need to address the issues of renegotiation and retrading, which might make the implementation of the optimal contracts via dispersed securities unstable. Following this, we derive empirical implications and relax some of the assumptions.20

fn.p: Bankruptcy laws that do not enforce absolute priority can easily be accommodated.

While the specific optimal contracts that arise in the model, debt and equity are clearly the most common securities in the real world, this fact itself is not meant to be viewed as a contribution of the paper. It is driven partly by the simple two‐state nature of the uncertainty of the model. For a more general structure of uncertainty, to derive the optimality of only two securities requires a significant amount of extra modeling assumptions about the probability distributions and the functional forms of private benefits and cost of effort functions. This is not the objective of the paper. We aim to explore interactions of features of the capital structure with features of the ownership structure of the firm. These can be explored most easily in the absence of further complications and restrictions.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Renegotiation and Retrading
sec.p: The model shows that it is optimal to have the firm owned by multiple investors. However, if renegotiation is possible, costless, and efficient, then these multiple investors might want to renegotiate until the outcome maximizes their total joint surplus. In other words, they might want to get together and act as if there were only one large owner who holds a “meta” security, a claim to the entire firm (this is akin to the Coase theorem and the Modigliani‐Miller irrelevance results). If that happens, then the type and amount of securities initially allocated to different individual investors would be unimportant.

We can show that the issues of renegotiation and retrading can be dealt with successfully in the current paper, and multiple investors with different claims are uniquely optimal and their allocations stable. In the model, investors would want to “negotiate” over one equilibrium feature: equity holders have the wrong incentives to make the joint‐value‐maximizing choice, because they are too dispersed to monitor at the optimal level.21While this is optimal ex ante, because it motivates the manager to work hard to ensure that equity retains control, it leads to ex post inefficient project choices. Equity holders could react in two ways: they could renegotiate their claims and act as if they were one investor or they could retrade their initial holdings so that one equity investor holds all the shares. This would make the single investor's incentive to monitor high, and he would acquire enough information to restore ex post efficiency.

For small, dispersed investors, getting together and renegotiating (to act as one) is not helpful. Their original difficulty in reaching the efficient outcome results from an information deficiency. Each holds too small a stake to make it worth while to monitor.22Bringing all the small, uninformed investors together to act as one does not “magically” produce new information; hence, it does not restore ex post efficiency. The only remaining possibility is that the small investors retrade and consolidate all shares with one investor, who then monitors.

As we will show, allowing investors to retrade also does not allow equity holders to change the outcome. In fact, investors chose not to retrade. This result is driven by the following intuition: small investors, when they observe an identifiable party (like a large shareholder) attempting to consolidate shares, do not sell their shares if they can anticipate that holding on to them leads to a higher return. In other words, because trading in large blocks is not entirely anonymous in most equity markets,23large shareholders have to share any rents they create from acquiring blocks. Imagine a stock currently selling at $50 per share. Furthermore, assume that, if the largest current shareholder can acquire another 20% of the stock, the market value would increase to $60. It is unlikely that the large shareholder could purchase the 20% block for the original $50 per share—or any price much below $60. In fact, it is well known that large blocks sell for a premium in markets (see Barclay and Holderness1989,1991). To formally address this issue, we adopt the same assumption as the previous literature (see, e.g., Grossman and Hart1980; Admati, Pfleiderer, and Zechner1994; Pagano and Röell1998; and Burkart et al.1997):
Assumption2. Trading by large shareholders is not anonymous.

The following proposition shows that, under this condition, the optimal dispersion or concentration of equity stakes is stable. If the large shareholder attempts to reduce his stake, then firm value is expected to fall (due to the resulting lower monitoring). Since trading is not anonymous, the selling large shareholder bears most of the cost of this fall in firm value on every share he attempts to sell. Furthermore, any share he retains also suffers the decline in value. Hence, selling is not optimal. Acquiring shares, of course, increases expected firm value, due to the higher resulting amount of expected monitoring. However, since trading is not anonymous, the gains in firm value are realized by those who sell their shares to the large shareholder, as they would sell only once the price offered approaches the expected ex post value of the firm. Of course, the large shareholder alone still bears the entire additional cost of increased monitoring. Hence, the net benefits are lower than the net costs and the large shareholder does not want to increase the block size ex post.
Proposition2. The equilibrium remains unchanged, even if renegotiation and retrading are allowed.
Proof. See the appendix.

More precise predictions could be derived if one is willing to specify some intermediate case, where some amount of trading is anonymous with some probability. This might lead to interesting predictions for countries that have less‐effective disclosure rules for insider trades and large block‐holder trades than the United States. Of course, this would necessitate an estimate of the functional form for the amount of trading that is anonymous, which would depend on initial block size, amount of trade, trade direction, liquidity, and other variables. This analysis is beyond the scope of the current paper.24

fn.p: All other decisions made in equilibrium are ex post efficient. Hence, there is no role for renegotiation.

Hiring a monitor is generally not possible for small investors, because most types of information cannot easily be verified and sold (see, e.g., Stein2002). Intuitively, the monitor would have to be monitored.
For example, in the United States, a large shareholder has to identify herself and declare her intentions once more than 5% of shares have been acquired.

Note that the predictions about which direction of trade would occur in equilibrium are difficult to make without adding a lot of assumptions about functional forms. On the one hand, the large shareholder might want to anonymously acquire shares to then increase firm value through increased monitoring. On the other hand, the large shareholder might want to anonymously sell shares to economize on monitoring costs, which the large shareholder has to bear alone.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Implications and Extensions
sec.p: In this section, we first examine the comparative statistics of the optimal equity ownership concentration and its relationship to features of debt. In particular, we examine the issues of debt dispersion, debt covenants, nonlinearity of return rights, as well as the creditor‐friendliness of the bankruptcy law and the representation of debt holders on the corporate board. The contribution of the current paper is that we can relate these debt‐side effects to the optimal equity ownership structure of the firm. After this, we relax two of the model's assumptions to derive further implications: (1) we allow for monetary managerial incentives, and (2) we distinguish between long‐term and short‐term agency problems.

The main conclusion of this section is the following: because management is motivated to “do the right thing” by the difference between the toughness of debt following poor performance and the relative weakness of equity following good performance, we can conclude that the powers of debt to control management are a complement to (and not a substitute for) the powers of equity to control management. In other words, we are more likely to observe strong equity together with strong debt and weak debt together with weak equity. For example, we are more likely to observe more‐concentrated equity in countries where the bankruptcy laws are more creditor‐friendly and where debt holders are more likely to have seats on the board of directors. This should provide some guidance for any empirical work trying to link ownership structure and capital structure in cross‐sectional or cross‐country studies. One example of evidence consistent with these results is Berger, Ofek, and Yermack (1997), who find a positive association between equity owners' powers vis‐à‐vis management and debt levels.25

fn.p: Studies like La Porta et al. (1997), Shleifer and Vishny (1997), and Franks et al. (1996) provide some related evidence in different contexts. It should be possible to extend these empirical analyses to formally test the ideas of the present paper.

sec.title: Optimal Equity Dispersion

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Dispersed Debt and Optimal Equity Dispersion
sec.p: Dispersed debt holders face the same free‐rider problem that dispersed equity holders face when it comes to monitoring management. Because the toughness of debt holders acts to discipline management, dispersing debt has a negative effect on firm value. That is why proposition 1 leads to an optimal α D =1. Hence, we have to appeal to reasons outside the model for the existence of dispersed debt. These could include, among many other things, regulatory, liquidity, risk‐diversification, or transactions‐costs motives, as well as hold‐up concerns discussed in the previous literature (Rajan1992; Mahrt‐Smith2003). The contribution of this paper is that we can relate this debt‐side effect to the optimal ownership structure on the equity‐side of the firm. Formally, let us assume the following.
Under this additional assumption, we can make the following statement.
Proposition3. If debt is dispersed, then equity dispersion is greater than in the case of concentrated debt. Formally,

The intuition is simple: More dispersed debt holders monitor less, and management can expect to be overruled less often. Hence, if management is to be motivated to put in effort to keep equity holders in control and debt holders at bay, then equity holders have to appear comparatively even weaker than the dispersed debt holders.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Nonlinear Return Rights
sec.p: Up to this point, the analysis was done under the assumption that both equity and debt holders have linear return rights.26However, nonlinear return rights can complement and amplify the previous results. Dewatripont and Tirole (1994) show that the return rights associated with the security that has control rights following low managerial effort should not necessarily be linear in cash flows (they should be concave, like debt cash flows). The assumption that leads to the result is that the variance ofc 2depends on the choice of γ.

Dewatripont and Tirole show that debt holders, with their concave return rights, insist on lower‐risk project choices. These could be liquidation, low‐growth but low‐risk business strategies, asset sales and layoffs, and the like. As long as these choices are less desirable to management than other, more risky options (Dewatripont and Tirole provide good, intuitive arguments for this), this would provide extra motivation for management to avoid debt control. Of course, the contribution of this paper is that the concavity of the debt return rights also affects the optimal level of equity dispersion. Using the concavity (which is related to the level of debt and its seniority) to commit to be tough on management in the low state allows the investors to give the manager less flexibility (e.g., effective control) in the high state without destroying managerial initiative. Hence, less‐dispersed equity and more equity‐control rights become optimal. This is exactly what Berger et al. (1997) find in the data.
To operationalize the intuition of Dewatripont and Tirole in the context of the present model, we make the following additional assumption.

Assumption4. Making the return rights of debt holders more concave induces them to prefer projects that are less attractive to management (i.e., φ I is raised followingc 1=c
l ).
We can now prove the following proposition.
Proposition4. Making debt return rights more concave increases equilibrium optimal equity concentration.
Proof. See the appendix.

fn.p:
While we did, of course, use ordinary debt and equity in the previous sections, there were no nonlinearities to worry about at the time of decision making. This is because the cash flow restriction in assumption 1, part 5 ensured that debt was either risk free (following high first‐period cash flows) or the sole owner (following bankruptcy). This left debt returns linear at the time of decision making. Also, because debt followingc 1=c
h was risk free, equity return rights were also de facto linear whenever equity holders made decisions. This section can be interpreted as relaxing the cash flow assumption in assumption 1, part 5.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Debt Covenants, Board Representation for Lenders, and Bankruptcy Laws
sec.p:
This section looks more closely at other features of debt contracts and their relationship to equity concentration. Rajan and Winton(1995)show that the presence of debt covenants increases the monitoring activity of lenders by increasing the sensitivity of a lender's returns to information. Inasmuch as monitoring is a hallmark of individual lenders, this result applies best to bank debt covenants. In the current model, additional monitoring reduces the informational advantage that the manager has vis‐à‐vis the lenders and hence reduces the effective control of the manager followingc 1=c
l . This is beneficial, because it increases the efficiency of project choices under debt control. An important side effect of increasing debt toughness through the presence of debt covenants is that it now becomes feasible to decrease α E without violating the manager's incentive compatibility constraint. In other words, effective bank covenants should lead to more concentrated equity in equilibrium.

A similar result can be derived with respect to board representation by large lenders. While this practice is not uncommon in the United States (more than 30% of firms according to Kroszner and Strahan2001), it is even more prevalent in other economies like Germany and Japan. Board representation for large investors can have multiple consequences, many of which are beyond the scope of this paper. However, as a simple illustration of the effects developed in this paper, assume that allowing investors to sit on the board leads to the investors having a lower cost of becoming informed about the firm's available project choices. This again makes debt holders more powerful, increasing managerial incentives to exert effort. Consequently, in equilibrium, more concentrated equity can now be sustained without destroying managerial initiative.

Last, bankruptcy law can be more or less creditor‐friendly (see Franks et al.1996, among others). This can be modeled as high or low costs for lenders to overrule managers followingc 1=c
l . “Tough” bankruptcy laws can thus be related to the equilibrium equity ownership structure with the model in this paper. The prediction would be to observe more‐concentrated equity in countries with more creditor‐friendly bankruptcy laws (e.g., Germany). To summarize these effects, we assume the following.

Assumption4.
1.
Bank covenants increase the incentive for lenders to become informed (i.e., φ I is raised followingc 1=c
l ).
2.
Lender representation on the corporate board decreases the cost of monitoring (i.e., θ is lowered followingc 1=c
l ).
3.
Creditor‐friendly bankruptcy laws reduce the cost for lenders to monitor and overrule management (i.e., θ is lowered followingc 1=c
l ).
We can now derive the following result.
Proposition5. Board representation for lenders, creditor‐friendly bankruptcy laws, and effective bank covenants are associated with more‐concentrated equity.
Proof. See the appendix.

Kroszner and Strahan(2001)show that bankers are represented on boards more often in countries where concentrated shareholdings are more common. This is consistent with the model in this paper. Again, more broadly, debt and equity powers are complements rather than substitutes.

sec.label: E.
sec.title: Monetary Incentives
sec.p: It is important to understand why more‐traditional methods of providing incentives fail to provide the first‐best outcome. The obvious alternative is to use monetary incentives (salary, stock options, and bonuses) to provide managerial incentives. While these almost surely are part of any optimal mechanism, we show that extending the manager's preferences to include utility from monetary payments does not make the capital and ownership structures superfluous. This is true even if monetary payments to the manager are optimally designed and allowed to depend on all contractible variables in the model.
We show that using the monetary incentives alone is less efficient than using the optimal capital and ownership structure.27
Proposition6. Using optimally designed monetary incentive schemes can lead to lower firm value than using the optimal ownership and capital structure.
Proof. See the appendix.

This result is driven by the fact that the private benefits of the manager cannot be transferred to the investors (at least, not dollar for dollar). In other words, as the manager is paid a salary, the cost of the salary is not offset one for one in improved performance as long as the private benefits of the manager increase or decrease at a different rate than firm cash flows. A manager's salary is an expensive (and imperfect) incentive mechanism as long as the private benefits that the manager derives from control are large when compared to her wealth but small when compared to the effect the managerial discretion has on overall firm performance. Since management “consumes” the private benefits in any case (they cannot be converted to cash and traded off against cash flow effects), the firm might as well utilize the effects of the private benefits by giving management some control as a reward, rather than fighting the effects of private benefits by promising high salaries att=0, and then insisting on slightly more cash‐flow efficient projects att=1, even though they are highly undesirable to management.

On a technical note, one can view the allocation of effective control (or power) via the ownership structure as an additional instrument (one that cannot be simulated by cash payments, because γ is not contractible) that can be used to provide managerial incentives. In particular, it is an instrument that could come at a low cost, as the state‐contingent allocation of private benefits might have large incentive effects without having a large direct cost in terms of foregone cash flows.

fn.p: We must make one modification to the current set of assumptions. Because the manager's wages can depend onc 2but the project choice γ is assumed to be noncontractible, we have to break the one‐to‐one mapping that currently exists between γ andc 2=φ I γ. Previously, this was immaterial. We do this by allowing for some uncertainty: Second‐period cash flows are nowc 2 =φ I γ+∊, where ∊ is random. Since now different choices of γ can lead to the same cash flows, contracts can includec 2without implicitly being written on γ.

sec.label: F.
sec.title: Long‐Term Versus Short‐Term Agency Problems
sec.p: One implication of the model is that the optimal level of dispersion for equity shares depends on the nature of the agency problem in the firm. To make this more transparent, we extend the model so that there are two entirely different managerial moral hazard problems: long‐term firm‐specific investments (say, in project discovery and development) and short‐term project selection. Dispersion of equity shares is beneficial to one of the problems (long‐term investments), because it motivates the manager by protecting the rents she creates. However, dispersion is harmful to the other (project selection), because it leaves some freedom to the manager to choose nonoptimal projects. Hence, firms should have more‐dispersed equity if long‐term firm‐specific investments are relatively more important than short‐term project choice. This result may be of particular interest in examining the evolution of firms over their life cycle. Firms that need to invest for the long run (say, growing pharmaceutical firms) may require more dispersed ownership. These same firms,when they have reached the zenith of their development cycle and are mainly harvesting the rents of their previous investments through various projects, should have active large outside shareholders. To formalize this intuition, we introduce the following extension of the model.

fn.p: For empirical work, this would require the difficult estimation of a functional form for the private benefits function, as well as an identification of what proportion, if any, of firm value can be expropriated from minority shareholders.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
This paper examines interaction effects of the capital structure and ownership structure in manager‐run corporations. These effects are expressed as empirical predictions, which include the following:
1.
Strong, concentrated equity ownership is associated with strong, concentrated debt holdings.
2.
If long‐term firm‐specific investment is important, then the equity should be more dispersed.
3.
Board representation by banks is desirable, especially if equity ownership is concentrated.
4.
Environments with weak (tough) bankruptcy procedures may be associated with relatively dispersed (concentrated) equity ownership patterns.
5.
Tough debt covenants may be more prevalent in environments that also favor large equity holders.

As a negative result, the model predicts that observing concentrated or dispersed equity ownership alone should not necessarily lead to observing differences in firm performance, unless one controls for the firm's capital structure. This finding is consistent with the wide variation of equity ownership structures observed both across countries and within countries. Simply put, unless all mechanisms that affect the allocation of effective control (equity dispersion, capital structure, board representation, legal system, debt concentration, etc.) are taken into account, tests for a relationship between equity concentration and firm performance can at best be consistent, but they will not be very powerful. Finally, the optimal incentives provided by the capital and ownership structure cannot be simulated by a carefully designed monetary incentive scheme.
